title: lent 2019 giving up vices jesus easter
story: Let’s take a closer look at why it is so important and why people give up one of their vices during this time...Lent is the six week period leading up to Easter Sunday.The actualis  days – however,  of these are fasting days and six are Sundays.Sundays in Lent are not counted in the forty days because each Sunday represents a mini-Easter.The period of Lent is seen as a time of solemn observance and preparation for the celebration of the death and resurrection of Jesus at Easter.From its start on Ash Wednesday until its conclusion on Easter Sunday, Lent has been a traditional time for fasting or giving something up or abstinence.The word Lent comes from the Anglo Saxon word lencten, which means spring.The forty days represent the time Jesus spent in the wilderness, enduring the temptation of Satan and preparing to begin his ministry.It can also be seen to mirror the  hours that Jesus spent in the tomb prior to his resurrection.Lent will begin on Ash Wednesday – which in  is March .Lent lasts  days with the Sundays seen as celebrations and not counted.Good Friday is also traditionally a day of fasting and penance.Many Christians will use Lent to commit to fasting, choosing to abstain from certain foods, habits or vices.The fasting and abstinence is meant to mirror the experience of Jesus Christ and his experience of fasting in the desert.Traditionally, Christians would fast during the  days of Lent, meaning they would have only one full meal a day and two small snacks.However, nowadays Christians choose to abstain from something in particular – like a food item or luxury like chocolate or caffeine, or a particular habit like drinking or smoking.In today’s technological age, others choose to give up social media or even using their phones.Generally, those observing Lent will also aim to perform one positive act for each of the days between Ash Wednesday and Easter Sunday.These positive acts can include calling up someone who is alone, donating to a worthy cause, clearing up after dinner and letting someone go ahead of you in a supermarket queue.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: let notre dame relight pride in christian values
story: On Monday evening, most terribly, flames on an impossibly larger, more savage scale licked through that ancient cathedral, destroying its roof timbers, toppling its spire and reducing its historic interior to a smouldering shell.Any fire has a hypnotic quality. Any blaze has destructive power. Yet the Notre Dame disaster leaves a greater sense of obliteration. Just look at the crowds of Parisians, many of them youngsters, who wept and clutched one another and sang mournful hymns as they watched Monday’s devastation.Their grief, and the awed horror of countless millions around the world who saw events unfold on TV, was not the normal reaction of onlookers rubber-necking at an accident. The loss of that old building left a deeper anguish. Why James Mates, reporting for ITV’s News At Ten that night, proved his value when he reached for an explanation.“Our time here is brief,” said Mates. “These structures — the greatest creations of mankind — are supposed to be permanent. Few can have imagined seeing one destroyed before our eyes.”These were good words. Notre Dame dates to the th and th centuries. To stand beside such an edice reminds us of our human smallness.The great cathedrals of Western Europe took centuries to build. Beside such projects, the longest human le feels butterfly-short. You run a hand over the old stones of a place like Notre Dame and you are struck by a sense of your own impermanence.You don’t have to be churchy to feel this way. There are other forces at work in our Notre Dame agony, emotions that a modern broadcaster might hesitate to mention. Notre Dame contained more than altars and crosses and pews.Its walls sheltered things far greater than the priceless artworks which burned. Notre Dame was a repository of the concepts of civilisation and nationhood and beauty and Christianity.It may be politically incorrect to say so but Monday’s fire, to many of us, felt like a metaphor for the recent conflagration of those precious moral concepts. French president Emmanuel Macron, who rushed to the scene, had this to say: “Notre Dame is our history, our literature, part of our psyche, the place of all our great events, our epidemics, our wars, our liberations, the epicentre of our lives.”Macron announced a national project to rebuild the cathedral because, “it is our profound destiny”. All this was noble and fair. But measure it against the record of the liberal political class he embodies. The Macrons and Merkels of this world — like the Blairs and Camerons and Cleggs and so many other equivocating cultural cowards — have long preached secularisation. They have diluted Christian values in our laws and public le.One recent Archbishop of Canterbury even told us it might be a good idea to have sharia law in Britain.These political leaders have imposed education systems that fail to teach youngsters to be proud of Western art and religion. They have scoffed at national pride and national flagsand lied to us about the federal element of the European Union.Out of sheer political dogma, post-war politicians bigged up modernist architecture, even though the public hated it. Much-loved vistas were destroyed and our capital cities’ skylines were wrecked when mayors approved show-off skyscrapers.We were told to be ashamed of past national historical triumphs such as the British Empire, which was allegedly racist and supremacist. Tradition was bad. Dferent was good. How come such leaders appreciate antiquity and the values represented by a great cathedral such as Notre Dame only when it has gone up in smoke One of the defining images of the Second World War was that photograph of St Paul’s Cathedral at the height of the Blitz, the dome standing proud amid Hitler’s bombs. The picture captured an idea of British defiance, of our country’s decency withstanding a Nazi dictator’s barbarism. It still makes one’s neck prickle with patriotism.What will we in future feel when we see that image of Notre Dame ablaze on Monday night  Might it come to represent the torching of Christendom in Europe It is said that the Paris fire brigade was slow out of the traps. Might that be a metaphor for a wider carelessness by politicians who have seen our culture in peril and failed to act It is no great secret that churches in France and other continental countries have been in a spiral of neglect for decades. A few years ago I visited a major church in Coutances, northern France, and found dead pigeons on the floor and broken panes in the windows.We have done better in Britain where, despite financial problems, our cathedrals and parish churches continue to be a great glory. The Church of England gets plenty of things wrong but it deserves credit for this.That Notre Dame and some of her treasures have been destroyed in Holy Week, as though roasted in the very fires of Hell, is a challenge to our already-dented morale. It seems cruel and may leave churchgoers agape as they try to identy the Almighty’s purpose.If God is working his purpose out, He has an odd way of going about it.But Easter is about renewal. Maybe that should be our pointer.Let this ghastly fire act as a spark to our resolve to relight a sense of pride in Europe’s Christian tradition.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says donald tusks second referendum dream
story: He has a habit of letting the Brussels cat out of the bag. By suggesting every delay to Brexit makes a second referendum more likely, he’s done it again.It’s something for MPs to reflect on before theyto Parliament.Do hard Brexit Tories really want to continue their st century version of the Charge of the Light Brigade, rushing into a vote that would be the final  triumph of the Remain establishment And do those Remainer MPs who put leaflets through doors in  promising to respect the vote really want to face the wrath of voters in a future General Election, after they’ve disregarded the biggest democratic mandate the  country has ever seen A second referendum would destroy the public’s faith in democracy. The early stirrings of that will no doubt be seen in the European elections, when the two major parties will surely receive an almighty kicking.The lesson is clear. Pass a deal — only one of which realistically exists — do it quickly and deliver on . million votes.The consequences of failing to do so don’t bear thinking about.THE devastation of beautul Notre Dame must be a wake-up call in Westminster.For years, staff working in the Houses of Parliament have warned that the building is on the brink of disaster. It already requires -hour fire patrols and is packed full of patchwork wiring that could go up at any moment.The news that grandees are planning to delay a much-needed restoration for years, then, is deeply concerning.Not especially because of Parliament’s current inhabitants — indeed we cannot think of a more sorry bunch of MPs and Peers to have ever sat on its benches, making a dog’s breakfast of Brexit and then swanning off on holiday.Nor are we pretending that in an ideal world we wouldn’t rather spend the refurbishment money  on more worthwhile priorities.But the idea of  Parliament burning long into the night is one we don’t want to contemplate.This decision can’t be kicked into the long grass any longer.IT’S another momentous day for those political whizzes in The Independent Group.Fresh from having their preferred name knocked back, they’ve now been told their logo isn’t allowed either.Perhaps, rather than being an  anti-Brexit party, they might consider something better suited to their organisational skills.A boozy night at a brewery, perhaps Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The account posts pictures of people with Maddies face photoshopped on and makes jokes about the tragic tots disappearance.Heart doctor Gerry, , and former GP Kate, , now a medical worker, are warning the offenders “to think twice” before mocking Madeleine and in so doing hurting their family, a close pal said.The couple from Rothley, Leicestershire, face the painful th anniversary of her kidnap in just two weeks.So far the twisted account has posted six pictures in the last week and the account has , followers.The disgusting captions refer to the childs disappearance in , including one that says Felt cute, might disappear later.Another reads: No one said hide and seek finished so I ghosted for a likkle  years but mans back for good.Three-year-old Maddie disappeared from her familys Portuguese holiday flat on May ,  - triggering a global search which has failed to find the child.A friend of Maddies parents said: “Kate and Gerry are still having to put up with this ridiculous rubbish. title: emily thornberry champagne socialist game of thrones
story: The Shadow Foreign Secretary hit back to tell the Instagram prankster she was a vodka and oyster socialist instead after the fancy millennial dinner party.She posted a snap of the feast she had to celebrate the new series of the smash TV show.The caption said: Game of Thrones Supper: White Walker cocktails caullower weirwoods dragon eggs house of Tyrrell crisps oysters  ice with fire  fiery fish stew. #yikes #allgoingabitfar  #millenialscooking #GameofThronesShe put on her story that the cocktails were made with vodka, triple sec and chickpea juice with blue food colouring.But one user piped up to comment: Champagne socialist.And Ms Thornberry quickly snapped back: Blue vodka and oyster socialist to you mate.Another commenter added: Thats socialism for you Em.Game of Thrones ed to our screens for a final season on Monday evening.And fans definitely werent disappointed after a two year-long wait to find out what happened since the end of the last one.

title: pupils foreign language gcse post brexit
story: In a bid to boost Britain’s bilingual skills Schools Minister Nick Gibb has set a target of getting three in four of all pupils studying and taking a foreign language GCSE by .Currently just under half of kids in England and Wales sit a foreign language GCSE.But from September all secondary school starters will be expected to study one and take the exam.And to get the numbers up schools will be assessed on the proportion of pupils studying foreign languages.As well as being held to account by Ofsted inspections, schools will also be judged on their foreign languages take-up in league performance tables.The Government has set a goal of  per cent of pupils achieving an English Baccalaureate , which is the core group of subjects seen as key for further education and includes a foreign language.Ministers want this target to be reached by , rising to  per cent by . Currently just  per cent of pupils are on course to get an EBacc - with languages the main reason keeping the numbers down.The Government has not set the target at  per cent because . per cent of pupils are on special needs plans, while roughly one in  currently are not able to take five or more GCSEs.Mr Gibb told The Sun that Brexit makes it even more important that Brits can speak a foreign language.He said: “As we leave the European Union and raise our profile in global markets, it is no longer acceptable for the UK to languish at the bottom of international league tables of the ability to speak foreign languages.“We need to ensure the next generation is far better than the current generation at communicating with the world.“An affinity with at least one foreign language will give young people the confidence to travel and work abroad. It will help our businesses to export our products, services and ideas.”Languages are compulsory at Key Stage , which covers Years , and .But the proportion of teenagers taking language GCSEs halved between  and  after Tony Blair’s Labour government no longer compelled -year-olds to sit exams.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says cops stop indulging eco activists london
story: As self-defeating campaign tactics go, shutting downpublic transport in our biggest cities is right up there. What next Chaining themselves to wind turbines so they can’t spin round  Dumping plastic bottles in the Thames to protest against ocean pollution The leaders of this “movement” are exactly who you’d expect.A pompous double-barrelled halfwit barely out of public school who stormed out of a Sky News interview because he didn’t like a question he was asked.A crank who is convinced psychedelic drugs gave her “the codes of social change”.Predictably, the sandals-and-socks brigade are almost all fully pledged to the Corbyn cause.The fact is that Britain has a good story to tell on “going green” — in truth we’re doing as much as anywhere,not more. Emissions are down  per cent since .The police have indulged these cretins for long enough.Time to get our country back up and running.HATS off to TSB, a bank that — it appears — may actually be interested in helping out its customers. Maybe it’ll catch on.Every day a new story reaches us of Brits being fleeced by scammers, with banks barely lting a finger to compensate them. So TSB’s pledge to fully repay punters who’ve been taken for a ride is long, long overdue.So far other banks have only signed up to a half-baked code of conduct which won’t give customers the protection they deserve — and, anyway, is only funded until the end of the year.A decade on from the financial crisis, there is still precious little sign that the banks understand the scale of the  public anger directed towards them.They must respondthey want to restore lost trust — in themselves, and in capitalism at large.GERMANY’S economic forecasts have been sliced in half — worth bearing  in mind next time Parliament’s Remain cheerleaders predict plague and pestilence once we leave the EU.The doom-mongers argue that only by staying at the heart of Brussels’ bureaucratic beast can we possibly hope to keep our economy moving.Well, no country is more “EU” than Germany, and its economy is proving far less robust than its motors.The Project Fear merchants were wrong in , and they’re wrong now.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leftie activists tearful when jeremy corbyn ignored them glued up next to his london house
story: Climate change demonstrators who chained themselves up to the Labour leaders fence were upset after he declined to speak to them.The four, from Stroud in Gloucestershire, tried to offer them chocolates in a paper bag marked Jeremys love hamper but he declined.They were outside there for hours and looked tearful after seeing Labour boss walked right past them and didnt say a word.Skeena Rathor, , a Labour councillor from Stroud, told The Times: I felt embarrassed. I felt sad. That’s it.And Richard House, , a Labour member, added: We feel some guilt to have done something that has placed someone’s family le under duress.It’s mortying.And David Lambert, , who claimed to have walked for eight days from Stroud, said: “Jeremy Corbyn is a key figure in expressing Extinction Rebellion’s demands.”Tracee Williams, , said: We’re decrying our own action, and that shows the gravity of the situation.But the Labour boss did offer to meet the protesters about climate change, which led them to unlock themselves and leave the scene in North London.It came as part of another day of chaos thanks to lefties in the capital who have caused travel woes for thousands.Protesters from Extinction Rebellion glued themselves to the top of a DLR train carriage at Canary Wharf earlier, and theres plans to take action on the tubes too.And thousands are camping out in tents in Oxford Circus, Parliament Square and Waterloo Bridge causing chaos for half a million Londoners.Eco warriors have demanded that the Government declares a climate emergency.But Micheal Gove said this morning: we’ve got the message, we understand that action needs to be taken.He added: Some of the activity that’s been going on on the streets has actually stopped people doing their jobs and also impeded, for example, people getting around London in a way that’s appropriate.And ex-Home Secretary David Blunkett demanded the Government use the full force of the law against those who are engaging in childish acts of sabotage.He wrote in the Daily Mail that their protests were only making things worse with their bullying tactics.

title: girl with back to front legs walks
story: The one-in-a-million condition meant that Victoria Komada’s legs were deformed with missing bones.Doctors said the three-year-old faced losing both limbs to the condition — known as bilateral tibial hemimelia.But her parents raised £, for surgery in the US and she can now walk, run and play sport.Victoria, mum Marzena Drusewicz, , and dad Dariusz Komada, , ed to Norwich on Monday after two ops and nine months of rehab in Florida.Marzena, originally from Poland, said: “She was in a lot of pain all day and all night.“We had all had enough. It was horrible.“Now she is not in any pain at all and can walk normally and we can all start our le again.“We were so happy when she took her first steps we started crying.“We were on the way to the car and she said mummy, can I show you something ”Victoria’s right leg was amputated above the knee and pins put into her left leg, before a fixator was attached.Screws were twisted into her legs every day to move the bones into the right position.Her second operation saw the bones in the left leg fused together for strength. Just two days later Victoria could walk.Surgeon Dr Dror Paley said: “She can walk and run and do sports now. She has a superb result.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: meghan markle prince harry baby nicknamed clive cliveden house conceived
story: Staff at the posh country house hotel – where Meghan stayed the night before her wedding – have joked that the couple conceived their baby there.After the news broke that Harry and Meghan are expecting their first baby, due any day now, workers dubbed it a “Cliveden baby”.Meghan loved the £-a-night five-star hotel so much, she and Harry popped back regularly last summer and autumn.They stayed in a hideaway cottage in the grounds, enjoying romantic walks and lazy lunches.A source said: “Harry and Meghan were always popping back to Cliveden for romantic stays after their wedding.“They spent a number of days there last summer and autumn.“Staff are joking that their baby is a Cliveden baby andit’s a boy they should call him Clive, as they enjoyed their time so much there.“They often stayed in a very private cottage in the grounds, Spring Cottage, and not many people would know they were there.“But the ladies in their exercise classes were quite surprised when they used to walk by!“Meghan really fell in love with the hotel and particularly the history of the two famous women who lived there, Nancy Astor and the Duchess of Sutherland.”The Sun understands the couple particularly loved the National Trust grounds that the hotel is set in, and were often spotted walking hand-in-hand.Spring Cottage boasts three bedrooms, private gardens, its own kitchen and dining room, plus a private River Thames boat launch mooring for £, a night.The palatial mansion was built in  for the Duke of Buckingham. title: uk tiniest miracle baby home born
story: Isabella Evans was born at  weeks and given a five per cent chance of survival.She is now smiling for parents Kym Brown and Ryan Evans in Bishop’s Cleeve, Gloucs. They said: “She’s our little fighter.”Tiny tot Isabella weighed the same as a Coke can at birth — with hands smaller than p coins.At oz she was the smallest premature baby for  years.Her body was shorter than a pack of baby wipes and doctors put her in bubble wrap to keep her warm.Yet after several scares and two le-saving ops she left hospital after six months and is now beaming at home with parents Kym Brown, , and Ryan Evans, .Relieved Kym said: “Realistically she shouldn’t be here. There were so many times we could have lost her.“But she never stops fighting. We love her to bits. She’s perfect.”Kym joked: “We are going to wrap her in bubble wrap for the rest of her le!” Restaurant manager Kym had been due to give birth on September .But at  weeks her ankles started to swell, with no one at that stage realising it was due to pre-eclampsia, a ­condition which affects six per cent of pregnancies and can be fatal for mother and baby.Kym went to her local hospital in Gloucester where a scan showed Isabella had stopped growing at  weeks. Staff hoped the pregnancy could continue for a fortnight and transferred Kym to Southmead Hospital in Bristol as a precaution.A scan the next day revealed Isabella’s heart rate was dropping so Kym was rushed in for a caesarean.She said: “It sounds dramatic and scary now but at the time I was quite calm. I didn’t have time for it to sink in.It was worse for Ryan because he could see how fast things were moving and how ill I was getting. He thought he was going to lose us both.”Isabella was born on June  at  weeks. She was put in an incubator to help her breathe.Kym waited a week to hold her in blankets and a fortnight for their first skin-to-skin cuddle.She said: “It was love at first sight and the protective maternal instinct kicks in. I stayed with her every night she was in hospital.“She couldn’t feed or breathe at first so she had tubes for that.“A few times she knocked out her breathing tube and the nurses had to grab her off me and fit another as quick as they could.”At three weeks the couple learned Isabella had a hole in her bowel and would need surgery at another hospital, St Michael’s. Kym said: “We prepared ourselves for the worst so when we got the call to say the op had gone well I just said, ‘OK’. I was in shock.“The way I was coping was to expect the worst. When the good news arrived I couldn’t take it in.”Three months later Isabella needed a second bowel op. Again she pulled through. She also needed laser eye surgery at a few months old.Kym added: “She wore her first vest at three months and only then because we think it had shrunk in the wash at the hospital.The vest was smaller than my phone.”But what is remarkable is that any baby born weighing under ozhas a quite low likelihood of pulling through.For a baby weighing g to survive is extraordinary. The odds would be around one in .Being born so premature means the lungs and brain have not yet had a chance to fully develop. So there is a chance of chronic lung and developmental problems later in le.We know the goalposts are shting but we need research to better understand and prevent these very early deliveries.Even a week longer in the womb has a huge impact on survival.At four months Isabella could finally fit premature baby clothes.And on December  she was allowed to go home to Bishop’s Cleeve, Gloucs.Ryan, a chef, said: “That was one of the best feelings in the world.”Now aged ten months Isabella weighs around the same as a newborn at lb.Ryan added: “She’s being weaned off her oxygen support and is expected to make a full recovery.“We’ve just had a catch-up with her consultant and he was amazed with her progress.”Kym said: “She has a hernia and a hole in the heart but they are just monitoring those and hope they will put themselves right.“We can’t thank the doctors and nurses enough at all the hospitals. They are superheroes.”Isabella tipped the scales at g . Aaliyah Hart, of Birmingham, weighed gin  and is now .The world’s smallest baby, a boy, was born last August in Tokyo weighing just g . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: climate change demonstrators national embarrassment
story: For days we’ve had to watch them standing idly by, barely lting a finger as commuters faced chaos.And we’ve had to watch them whizzing around on protesters’ skateboards and dad-dancing to disco tracks.London Mayor Sadiq Khan, not one to take responsibilityhe can palm it off where, blames Government “cuts” for the Met Police’s failure to get a grip.It wasn’t “cuts” that meant a copper was making DJ requests rather than doing his job, though, was it Nor do the Met’s apparent financial troubles stop it employing  “specialist hate crime investigators”.There are now warnings that the title: friends using metal detectors dig up hoard of 14th century coins worth 150k
story: The amateurs excavated  over four days at an organised rally in a field.The treasure comprises  rare full-gold Edward III nobles from the Black Death era and  silver coins, thought to be from Edward I and II’s reigns.Finders Andrew Winter, , Tobiasz Nowak, , his brother Mateusz, , and Dariusz Fijalkowski, , kept guard each night in a tent beside the hole.Crane driver Andrew, of Blyth, Northumberland, said: “We just kept finding coins and digging.“My machine was like a hoover. To do it with my friends Tobiasz and Mateusz was so special.”The three spent an hour digging on a field near Hambleden, a village recorded in the Domesday Book of , without finding anything.They were on their way to another location when Andrews detector signalled a code which suggested it had detected a hammered silver coin - so he started digging.The trio turned over a clod of earth with two coins in it, and could see more in the hole.Then-stranger Dariusz, a dad-of-three and machine operator from Bristol, came found two silver coins around the same time.In detecting and treasure finding, anything over three coins is a hoard - and has to be declared to organisers. The area is then cleared.It was claimed jointly by the foursome, who were left to work alone.On the first day they found  silver coins and nine gold nobles, and all admit they barely slept due to excitement.Over three days the teams hoard grew to  silver coins plus fragments, and  gold nobles.Some of them have been doing the hobby for less than a year.The coins were dubbed the Hambleden Hoard, after the village in Bucks near the dig site.Their final sale proceeds will be split with the landowner.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: piers sadler climate change environment london transport
story: Here, protester Piers Sadler writes his letter to the nation about why theyre protesting .I AM a -year-old geologist. This letter to the people of the UK was written in a police cell, where I was held for six hours.The information is from my memory, having spent the past  years following climate science. I have never been an activist, nor have I been arrested before.I came to London to join the Extinction Rebellion and was camping at Marble Arch and protesting at multiple London sites until my arrest on Wednesday afternoon.The Extinction Rebellion aims are: For the Government to tell the truth about climate change, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by  and to form a Citizens Assembly to determine how we achieve this.Preventing climate catastrophe is the most important political, social, environmental and technical problem humanity has ever faced.The Inter-Governmental Panel on Climate Changeis the United Nations body which assesses all available science related to climate change. It suggests a number of routes to limiting the rise in global average temperatures to .C. It also tells us that an increase of C will have much worse effects.All pathways to a maximum .C rise require cuts of around  per cent in global emissions within about  years. To have any chance of achieving this, we need to take immediate action to drastically reduce emissions.So far we have caused global average temperatures to increase by .C since the end of the s. We are already seeing the spread of wildfires, hurricanes, drought, melting icecaps, sea levels rising, ocean acidication, coral reef die-off and the largest scale extinction of animal and plant species since the end of the dinosaurs.The IPCC is predicting C to C of warming based on our current trajectory. With these changes, the Earth will not look like the one we recognise today, but rather like the planet of million years ago. Then there was no ice, temperatures were inhospitable and sea levels much higher — dferences that would totally destabilise ecosystems and society.As climate change continues, human-induced effects are amplied by earth processes, such as methane from melting permafrost and reduced reflection of light back in to space as polar ice sheets shrink. These processes will make global heating worse and are sometimes called tipping points, as they can lead to runaway climate change where the human effects are no longer the main drivers — and they are impossible to halt.Since human climate change was first predicted by Swedish physicist Arrhenius in , thousands of scientists, working for decades in dozens of countries and disciplines, have come to a consensus that climate change is real and the effects catastrophic. There is no scientic debate to be had.The Government is complacent about the UK’s emission reductions, while failing to meet its own targets.Given the situation, I feel the Extinction Rebellion is our last best shot at getting governments to listen and start telling the truth.Once the truth is being told I believe that YOU will be urging the Government to act fast and vote accordingly.My involvement in the rebellion and my arrest are my heartfelt attempt to do whatever I can to help prevent the worst effects of climate change and the social, environmental and financial costs it will cause.I am sorry for the disruption caused to local businesses and commuters.I also apologise to the politan Police for the ersion of resources. My experience of the Met is that there has been an atmosphere of mutual respect between them and protesters.I ask that you, the people, become properly informed about climate change. I also ask that Government, businesses and public bodies start taking transformative action now to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to zero.Finally, I ask for a Citizens Assembly, a representative group of the population which will determine the direction we take to get to zero carbon and will take decisions out of the electoral cycle and political and financial influence.The protesters in London represent a broad church of opinion but I would say my opinions and background are typical.If you have read this far, thank you very much.PIERS writes his letter from a police cell – and for that reason, I cannot take him seriously. He and his fellow protesters might think their cause is noble, but breaking the law is not.Equality before the law is one of the most important principles of British justice. The expectation has always been thatyou commit a crime, you will do the time.Yet for days now, parts of central London have been overrun by a rag-tag band of climate change activists, Piers among them.Setting up makesht camps at Oxford Circus, Marble Arch, Waterloo Bridge and Parliament Square, members of Extinction Rebellion have blockaded roads. And they appeared to be doing so with the support of the politan Police and the force’s boss, the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan.Their cause is an important one, but like every good hostage taker, Extinction Rebellion has come armed with a list of demands, and protesters are prepared to be arrested to secure them. Yet even Extinction Rebellion must have been surprised the blockades were not removed for four days.Hundreds of thousands of Londoners have been suffering on a daily basis. Commuters cannot get to work as buses have been erted. Shoppers have had to abandon some of the busiest streets. Businesses can’t get essential supplies. Emergency vehicles are unable to take the quickest routes. The blockades have cost London millions.Nobody denies the activists are committing a crime by obstructing the streets. Until yesterday, police could be found helping them by acting as picket-line cheerleaders and traffic controllers. We have been told the police presence hasn’t detracted from usual police business. Which of us believes that Excusing their behaviour because it is an important and righteous cause ignores the problem that we are setting a precedent.The liberal, metropolitan elite cheering on the protesters should be careful what they wish for. Paris has been convulsed by violent protests that began in a similar way. Failure to apply the law of obstruction when the Yellow Vest movement started has cost France dear.Others with cause to be angry about politics will have learned the lessons from Extinction Rebellion’s successful action.Remain-backing Londoners may feel very dferently about the taking over of public spaceLeave supporters annoyed at the failure to secure Brexit hit the streets in peaceful protest. But they will have only themselves to blame. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: frankie boyle capitalism new world order
story: Which hardly narrows down the field of possibilities, I realise.You’re probably thinking it could be just about anything from ­Question Time or Politics Live to the Twirlywoos or Tree Fu Tom, given the slanted nature of our state broadcaster.So I’ll help you out.It was the final rallying call from a guest on BBC’s New World Order, hosted by Frankie Boyle, whose unlikely transformation into ­comedy’s White Knight of feminism ­continues to put even the reinvention of Piers Morgan as the undisputed saviour of breakfast television into the shade.For just a few short years ago, Frankie was making “jokes” about raping Victoria Pendleton, punching Jessica Ennis-Hill in the stomach and lots of other material that would’ve had the likes of Jim Davidson banned from everything for le.Frankie, though, hates the Tories and Brexit and thinks Jeremy Corbyn is “a decent person”, as terrorist-fawning anti-Semites go.So the BBC’s given him a third series of New World Order, his very own Church Of The Woke, which operates in exactly the same way as the previous two — with four or five guests who must adhere to some fairly strict “group think” rules.One has to be Sara Pascoe, another usually writes for , no one is allowed to be Conservative and there’s a built-in female majority that’s meant to make the BBC look all progressive, inclusive and lovely but doesn’t, because none of them are funny and they all just agree with everything Frankie says.A weekly discussion is built around a topical news event, where pretty much anything abusive and left-wing goes, and facts and truth are usually the first casualties.No space to list all of them here but during this current series I’ve seen Michael Forsyth described as a “Conservative MP” , Liam Fox cited as an example of a Cabinet “forged in British public schools”, even though he’s a council-house boy educated at his local comprehensive, and Frankie claiming Sleaford Mod Jason Williamson was expelled from Labour “during the Harriet Harman purge”.He wasn’t. He was expelled when Corbyn was leader for rather delightfully tweeting: “Dan Jarvis can lick my f***ing ar*e too. Posing c***.”A shame no one was on top of that detail, as I thought it would’ve added to the debate they were having about “male aggression” ruining politics.No matter, because this week we had a discussion on feminism and the open goal of Frankie Boyle asking“the biggest problem for women is the determination of some men to be objectionable”.It is, Frankie. It is.As he well knew, though, there was fat chance of any of his guests being brave or bright enough to point out there was a big problem sat right in front of them.They all live in a wilfully blind, hypocritical political universe and will ignore any personal and professional failings, no matter how obvious and odious, just so long as the person shares the same common enemy and goals as the rest of this toxic, left-wing BBC bubble.Althoughcolumnist and environmentalist George Monbiot did rather let the cat out of the bag with that end- of-show rant.“We’ve got to go straight to the heart of capitalism and overthrow it. But you said this was going to be a comedy programme, Frankie.”Oh George, how stupid and naive can you really be QVC, Katy Pullinger to Michelle Mone: “I can’t wait to see your wedding photos.” Britain’s Got Talent, David Walliams: “Sheila Simmonds, you are a very funny lady.” And Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins, Jeff Brazier: “I think I might surprise a few people with who I really am.”Not unless you’re really Kirk Douglas you won’t.CHANNEL ’s three-part series Let’s Talk About Sex is a perfect example of a good idea gone bad.For it’s one thing holding up old sex education films for well-deserved ridicule. It’s quite another when you get some of the biggest C-list ar*eaches in Britain to do the ridiculing.Namely, Ulrika Jonsson, Miriam Margolyes, Danny Dyer, Jeff Brazier, Stephen Mangan, plus Alastair Campbell and his daughter Grace, who’s every bit as likeable as her old man. The poor girl.Some of the others had brought a much smarter and better behaved child along for the ride as well, including Jeff, who’s set himself up as a “parenting expert”, these days, but took some delight in telling his -year-old sonBobby and the viewers: “There’s nothing more enjoyable than going from behind.”Jeff also had no idea he’d said something quite funny when he claimed an old menstruation cartoon reminded him of “Angry Birds”, probably because, like all of the celebs, he’s just too full of himself and his own lovely, enlightened modern ways to notice anything .In ten or  years’ time, of course, it’ll be their turn to be mocked by the next generation, who’ll probably also be wondering why prime candidate Alastair Campbell didn’t lead the male masturbation discussion, how Ulrika managed to keep a straight face discussing family planning issues, and why oh why oh why the camera didn’t cut straight to Stephen Mangan after the question: “Is this the end of a penis ”What a waste.Three, try a head transplant.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which former X Factor star joined the coaching  for the  series of The Voice UK ”Kev: “Molly Urs.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What animals are ridden in the rodeo event ‘mutton busting’ ”Angela: “Cows.”Bradley Walsh: “Which New Zealander stood on top of Mount Everest on May ,  ”And Ben Shephard: “When Labour rebranded itself in the s, the party leader was Tony who ”Shane: “Pass.” Hey, that’s showbiz.Liam Rosenior: “Brighton will have to dig their sleeves up.”Glenn Hoddle: “If the goalie makes a save, he saves the ball.”Matt Le Tissier: “Every single season it’s a close title race. Last season was dferent because City ran away with it.”OVER at week two of the Britain’s Got Talent auditions, a masked and mute psychic had Ant wonderinghe’d take off his disguise to reveal “someone we know, like your we”.Dec reckoned: “That would be a shock,” while the rest of the country thought it would probably be a much bigger oneit was actually Ant’s ex-we.One of the very few occasions when the show and its hosts were slightly out of tune with the nation as, quite unexpectedly, watching Britain’s Got Talent has become a joyful and funny experience once again.A feeling not unconnected to the fact, I suspect, that it’s eliminated all the sob stories in favour of pure entertainment, with the absolute pick of this week’s bunch being Gonzo, the manic Japanese tambourine player, and Israel’s Guy First, who brought the house down and hopes to go all the way to the live finals hand-farting Take On Me, by A-ha, and the Ghostbusters theme tune.I, for one, hope he does it as well – and any attempts at a cultural boycott are shoved right up the dark side of Roger Waters’ moon.Line Of Duty dropping the tantalising clue that H “Definately” can’t spell.Robbie Williams and Ayda Field demanding a rise on their £million X Factor pay, despite the sabbatical he took during the last disastrous run.The self-pitying sap from the Nescafe advert who wants people to “sit downyou can’t ­remember my name”.Married At First Sight angling for more gullible cringe-mongers when it had only just stopped humiliating the current batch.Alesha Dixon’s comedian mate getting Simon’s Golden Buzzer on Britain’s Got Talent.And Sara Pascoe, Gemma Collins, Dani Dyer, John Barnes, Desiree Burch and Samson Kayo. ’Cos Jonathan Ross is really rolling out the big guns for this series, isn’t he WORST quiz show answer of the week. Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Oscar-winning actress Rachel Weisz married which James Bond star in  ”Jordan: “Piers Morgan.”Not eventhe film’s called Diet Another Day.THIS week’s winner is the farmer from Shaun The Sheep and Line Of Duty ­legend Adrian “Ted Hastings” Dunbar.Sent in by Ricky, via email. story: NewsBBC admits Fiona Bruces correction in Diane Abbott row didnt go far enoughThe exchange on BBC Question Time saw Bruce claim Labour were behind in the pollsShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video fiona-bruce-happy-clary-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:[ REV- ],video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:[ REV- ],video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The BBC have admitted their correction of Fiona Bruceaposs row with Diane Abbott on Question Time did not go far enough.Labour complained after Ms Abbott was incorrectly challenged after claiming her party was “neck and neck” with the Tories in the polls. Fiona Bruce and political pundit Isabel Oakeshott said Labour was behind in the polls – but in the last  at the time it has trailed the Tories in four, led in four and tied in two. Correcting the claim on the show, Ms Abbott said: “Just as a point of information, currently we’re kind of, in the polls overall, we’re kind of level pegging”. But Ms Bruce interjected “But you’re behind, Diane…Definitely”.    On a subsequent episode, Ms Bruce claried her comments. She said: I was talking about a poll that came out on the day of the programme which suggested the Conservatives were ahead.The Shadow Home Secretary mentioned some other earlier polls that showed Labour in the lead.We should have made that context clear and Iaposm really happy to do that now. But after more than a dozen complaints from members of the public, the BBCaposs Executive Complaints Unit have admitted the correction didnapost go far enough.   In a ruling published this week, the Corporation said: Subsequent corrections on social media and on the BBC website “Corrections and Clarications” page made clear that Ms Bruce had in mind a poll published on the morning of the programme which showed a Conservative lead , while saying Ms Abbott was  “also right”  with reference to recent polling as a whole, and a correction by Ms Bruce in the  January edition of the programme echoed this. The ECU, while acknowledging these extensive efforts to set the record straight, took the view that the effect of Ms Bruce’s intervention went beyond generating confusion between dferent sets of polling data, suggesting that, contrary to what Ms Abbott had said, the overall data then current showed a definite Conservative lead, and that the corrections did not entirely recty that impression. , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:[ REV- ],video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the haunting final tweet posted by investigative journalist Lyra McKee shortly before she was shot dead during unrest in the streets of Derry. Ms McKee, , was caught in crossfire and shot in the head when a gunman fired a number of shots at police in what the force in in Northern Ireland is treating as a terrorist incident. Police have blamed the dissident republican group the New IRA for the journalistaposs murder as petrol bombs, bricks and bottles were hurled at police Land Rovers amid disturbances in Derry on Thursday night. At .pm, about four minutes before she was fatally wounded, Ms McKee posted a photo of the scene with flames and smoke visible in the distance. She wrote: Derry tonight. Absolute madness.    Award-winning Ms McKee, from Belfast, worked as an editor for Calornia-based news site Mediagazer, a trade publication covering the media industry. Her work has been published by The Atlantic, Mosaic Science, BuzzFeed and The Ferret. It is understood she had recently moved to Derry to live with her partner. In , Forbes Magazine named Ms McKee one of their  under  in media.  She had been working on a new book which had been due to be published in . In Thursday nightaposs incident, eyewitnesses claimed a masked figure stopped at the bottom of the road and fired shots up towards where Lyra was standing. People started to run for their lives, and Jake Hanrahan, a journalist who was at the scene, said Ms McKee was caught in crossfire. Assistant Chief Constable Mark Hamilton, of Police Service Northern Ireland, told reporters on Friday the dissident republican group the New IRA was probably responsible for the murder.  Police Service of Northern Ireland officers were carrying out a search operation in the Creggan area of Derry aimed at disrupting dissident republicans ahead of this weekendaposs commemoration of Irish independence, when a situation developed during which more than  petrol bombs were thrown at officers and two cars were hijacked and set on fire. During the unrest a gunman fired a number of shots at police, Mr Hamilton said. He said: Lyra McKee,  years old, was wounded. She was taken away in a police Land Rover to Altnagelvin Hospital but unfortunately she has died there. We have now launched a murder inquiry here in the city.   We believe this to be a terrorist act, we believe it has been carried out by violent dissident republicans, our assessment at this time is that the New IRA are most likely to be the ones behind this and that forms our primary line of inquiry. This is a horrendous act, it is unnecessary, it is uncalled for, it is totally unjustied. Ms McKee rose to prominence in  after a blog post called Letter to my -year-old self in which she spoke about the struggle of growing up gay in Belfast. In the five years since, her letter was turned into a short film, she became a published author with Angels With Blue Faces, and had recently signed a two-book deal with Faber  Faber, as well as appearing in domestic and international publications.  Named as one of the  under  in media by Forbes Magazine in , Ms McKee was cited for her passion of dig into topics that others donapost care about. Angels With Blue Faces, a non-fiction book about the Troubles-era cold case murder of South Belfast MP Rev Robert Bradford, was released in  and her latest book, The Lost Boys, is due for publication by Faber  Faber next year. The book, which described the author as a rising star of investigative journalism, focuses on the story of Thomas Spence and John Rodgers, who vanished near the Falls Road in west Belfast in November . In an earlier piece about the book, agent Janklow and Nesbit said: Lyra is a -year-old investigative journalist who grew up on Belfastaposs Cltonville Road, just off the infamous Murder Mile, the area which saw more casualties per square foot than any other part of the city during the Troubles.  Lyra is fascinated by the recent history of the city her focus as a journalist is the indirect ways the violence of war plays out, through its secondary waves of victims, and through the way trauma is passed on to subsequent generations. Like Anna Funderaposs Stasiland and Andy OaposHaganaposs The Missing, The Lost Boys will be an investigation, but also a portrait of a place of Belfast and of the Troubles, at the first moment in time where itaposs become possible to write about them historically . Mr Hamilton offered his deepest sympathies to Ms McKeeaposs family. And he said: But not only is it a murder of a young woman, it is an attack again on the people of this city. I stood here in January and we talked about the bomb and the act of violence against this city, and yet again we see another act of violence in this city which has had horrendous consequences and which will affect people for many, many years.  I would appeal to people, particularly this Easter weekend, to stay calm, I would appeal to people who are intent on violence to draw back, I would appeal to people with influence to use your influence and make sure this is peaceful weekend. Not only this weekend but going forward in this city. These acts of violence are bringing nothing to this city, all they are doing is bringing misery to one family, but also particularly to this city and also to our broader province. Grief-stricken friends and fellow journalists have paid tribute to Ms McKee. Matthew Hughes said he had been left devastated by the death of one of his closest friends. I just received the heartbreaking news that my friend @LyraMcKee was murdered tonight in a terrorist incident in Derry, he tweeted.  She was one of my closest friends. She was my mentor. She was a groomswoman at my wedding. I canapost imagine le without her, and yet now I must. Ann Travers, whose sister Mary was murdered by the IRA in , said Ms McKee was a kind, gentle, witty and stubborn soul. I have just heard, that my lovely friend Lyra was murdered tonight in Derry. I just canapost believe, that this witty, clever human being has been taken... Feel sick. Fellow journalist Peter McGuire said Ms McKee was a gted writer, a kind person and SO generous with her time and knowledge. So young - horric  heartbreaking news from Derry tonight, he tweeted.  Seamus Dooley, Irish secretary of the National Union of Journalists, wrote: Shocked by news that woman shot dead in Derry last night has been named locally as @NUJofficial Lyra McKee. We are shocked by killing of a journalist of courage, style and integrity. Sympathy to her partner, family and many friends. Lilly Dancyger, a New York-based editor at digital publication Narratively, said Ms McKee was dedicated to covering the lasting trauma  violence of the Troubles. Devastating to hear she was killed tonight by that same violence, she tweeted. Ms Dancyger shared an article written by Ms McKee about the families of Troubles victims. I was Lyraaposs editor on this story, and it was an honour. Sharing her work now is all I can think to do, she said. The Ferret, an online investigative journalism cooperative in Scotland which had published Ms McKeeaposs work, tweeted: We are deeply saddened to hear of Lyra McKeeaposs death. Lyra was a brilliant journalist who wrote for The Ferret. In  she won Scottish Refugee Council and Write to End Violence Against Women awards. Our deepest sympathies go out to Lyraaposs family and friends. Writer Brooke Magnanti, whose blogs were made into TV hit Secret Diary Of A Call Girl, said she was stunned by the news. She tweeted: I only knew her from online and a phone conversations after we were introduced by @GlasgaeLauraLee she struck me as a thoughtful journalist unafraid to challenge her own beliefs. Rare and precious. Deepest condolences to family and friends. Lisa McKee, creator of the hit Channel  programme Derry Girls, tweeted: Sickening, shameful and heartbreaking.

story: NewsPassengers could be WEIGHED before boarding flights in a bid to cut costsTech firm Fuel Matrix is reportedly talking with UK airlines about the installment of pressure pads at self check-in desksShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  APR News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPassengers could be weighed before boarding a flight in a bid to cut costs and the damage on the evironment. Tech firm Fuel Matrix is reportedly talking with UK airlines about the installment of pressure pads at check-in desks. The pads are understood to discreetly weigh a passenger as they pass through the airport, collecting date which is then passed to the flight deck. Pilots would reportedly then use the data to calculate exactly how much fuel is needed for the flight and reducing the amount wasted. Other options are believed to include security body scan machines which could record a personaposs weight.    The move is said to also help reduce carbon emissions by using up less fuel. Currently, airlines use an average weight of a man, woman and child to estimate their fuel needs.For men, they allow . stone, for women  stone and for children . stone, reports the Independent .However, Berkshire-based Fuel Matrix reportedly claims this calculation results in fuel wastage. Chief operating officer Nick Brasier told the Independent that most flights carry about one per cent more fuel than they need and burn about . to . per cent more fuel due to the extra fuel weight.     Brasier said: “We’re not suggesting people should stand on the scales, but airports could fit ‘pressure pads’ in the self-service bag drop area in front of each screen. “After the bag has been checked in, the system can ask, ‘Are you standing on the pressure pad ’ “If the passenger taps ‘Yes’, then the weight can be recorded and passed confidentially to the airline.”

title: paul routledge brexit takes across
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Brexit takes us across the border into a nightmareWhat I saw between Hungary and Serbia two days ago is the spectre haunting Dover and all the Channel portsShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  APR NewsopinionIve seen the future Jacob and it doesnt work! "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have seen the future, and it doesn’t work. On show, in all its road-chaos glory, on the southern border of the European Union between Hungary and Serbia. Stationary lorries double-parked for more than three miles, while armed guards faff about doing nothing. This is the shape of things to come, when EU and non-EU neighbours are on bad terms. The E motorway linking these two countries is a giant lorry park.My bus from Subotica in northern Serbia to Szeged in southern Hungary was held up for two hours. That’s nothing. Delays can last seven hours at peak holiday times. Passengers were herded through a grim transit shed for passport checks, while officials ransacked our luggage. Maybe they were looking for seditious literature. I only had the London Review of Books. No water, no food, a toilet charging € but closed.Drivers immobilised by the border go-slow that must have been ordered by Budapest’s hard-line ­government stood around in the chilly wind, swapping horror stories.They were from Germany and every nation in the Balkans and beyond, caught in a stand-off between an EU state and a non-EU. There was a migrants crisis here, but that’s mostly in the past after Hungary’s ­authoritarian leader Viktor Orbán put up a Trump-style fence.    What I saw there two days ago is the spectre haunting Dover and all the Channel ports. Brexit means balls-up for the truckers, wrecking a way of le built up over  years of free trade.So, thank you toff-twerp Jacob Rees-Mogg, monomaniac Sir Bill Carcrash, barmy Sir Peter Bonehead and all the other swivel-eyed Brexiteers who have brought us to this pass. They should get off their high horses and talk to the truckers of the E autoput. Or better still, listen. My first words above reference those of famous American journalist Lincoln Steffens, who wrote in  after a starry-eyed visit to the young Soviet Union: “I have seen the future, and it works.”

Walsh then sent a message to Apsley saying: Was you proud of me coming all that way to batter that bird She later said: I was out my face on drugs when I sent that message.During the attack in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester, Miss Hampson was punched by both Walsh and Apsley as she sat terried on a sofa. Her bank card was also taken and used to pay for Walsh to get a taxi home. Miss Hampson was left with bruising to her head, face and body plus scratched eyeballs, a cut lip and swelling to her face and a suspected fractured rib. She subsequently took an overdose due to her ordeal.    In a statement the victim accused the two women of having a capacity for evil and said: I have suffered from anxiety for four years and this incident had left my anxiety much worse and I have had to have my medication increased. At the time I was having fear that someone would come back and do it again. I am not sleeping very well. I fear going out on my own. I am not eating properly due to the stress and anxiety. Physically, I have a lump on my ribs following the assault. I am still in pain and taking painkillers. I have felt scared to stay at the woman refuge. I took an overdose four weeks ago and I have moved to live outside of Ashton-under-Lyme where I feel safe. I canapost work due to the high level of stress. If I ever saw them again I would be absolutely terried. I am scared of the capacity for evil they can have. Molly was supposed to be my friend. At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, Walsh from Adswood, Stockport was jailed for  months after she pleaded guilty to assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Apsley of Ashton-under-Lyne faced up to six months jail after admitting common assault but was freed with a  month community order after the court heard she was heavily pregnant and due to give birth to her first child.    The incident began on New Years Eve last year when Apsley and Miss Hampson met up for a few drink in their local pub. Prosecutor Craig MacGregor said: Starting at .pm they drank all night. Ms Hampson recalls being merry drunk, but was not falling over. Apsley invited a few people from the pub, including Ms Hampson, back to her flat to carry on. At the flat, Ms Hampson was speaking to some men in the bedroom, which was used as a smoking area. Apsley came in and asked to borrow Ms Hampsonaposs bank card to get money out to get some more beer. Ms Hampson agreed to this but then describes Apsley being aposgone for agesapos. When Apsley ed, she was with Gillian Walsh, who she called aposauntapos. Ms Hampson went into the room to see her and she had said something, but she doesnapost remember what. Without further ado, she got hit to the head. As Ms Hampson fled to the bathroom to get away from Walsh, three females followed her in. Walsh started to punch her repeatedly. Ms Hampson couldnapost get away until she dropped to the floor and slumped over the bath. Then Walsh walked away.  The prosecutor added: Ms Hampson said she wanted to be let out of the flat. She went into the living room and Apsley came in. The complainant sat on the couch and then Apsley punched her to the face, to her head and scratched her. Walsh then walked by the room and said: aposIaposm going to use the bank card to get money out to get a taxi homeapos. Ms Hampson was scared, hurt and just wanted to get out. She tried to phone the police but the third girl tells her not to call the police and takes her phone. The third girl then emptied her bag, took her belongings out and said to Ms Hampson: aposjust go and donapost involve the policeapos. Ms Hampson went back to the refuge and didnapost report matters to the staff but did tell the police. Her phone was used earlier in the evening by Apsley for her to make some texts. One of the replies to her read: aposWas you proud of me coming all that way to batter that birdapos. This was from Walsh and the Crown believe she was brought in for the assault. There was an element of planning and premeditation. Ms Hampson was a vulnerable person.  Walsh had five previous offences on her criminal record including a public order offence when she threatened a mother and her toddler as they were getting in their car and she said: Iaposm going to f***ing get you. She also had a previous conviction for assault occasional actual bodily harm in  when she got involved in a bar fight where she was seen to possess a kne, which was caught on the bars CCTV. Apsley had  offences on her record including assault whilst drunk. In mitigation Apsleyaposs lawyer Ian Metcalfe said: This was an ugly and repulsive incident and she is aware of that. But there was no evidence on the phone to suggest Miss Apsley summonsed Walsh. The text from Walsh is open to interpretation. Walsh who was unrepresented said: I am anxious and I have had some depression. I live with my son and my mum, my son has ADHD and has got some learning dficulties. My mum is  and struggles with her breathing. I was out my face on drugs when I sent that message. Sentencing Judge Tina Landale told the women: You have both pleaded guilty to assault on a lady who thought she was your friend. You Apsley were out on New Years Eve, you had a good evening, but something went wrong. After you got her back to your flat you borrowed her bank card to get some money out of the cash point to carry on drinking. You came back with Gillian Walsh, you had been using drugs and drinking alcohol. Things turned almost immediately as Walsh punched this lady a number of times and caused her some injuries to her face and her body. She wasnapost allowed to leave and whilst she was on the sofa you, Apsley punched her. These offences are serious. Both women were also made subject of a restraining order for three years, prohibiting contact with Ms Hampson. If you or someone you know is struggling with, there is help available. title: what good friday meaning behind
story: NewsWhat is Good Friday  Meaning behind it, traditions and why people eat hot cross bunsChristians commemorate the death of Jesus Christ on Good Friday. Heres everything you need to knowShareCommentsByDaisy Naylor:,  APR NewsGood Friday is a day of sorrow and mourning for many Christians around the world "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGood Friday is considered as one of the most important dates in the Christian calendar.It marks the beginning of Easter, as itaposs the first day of the Easter Triduum.In the UK Good Friday is a bank holiday, and there are ious traditions and customs observed by Christians around the world. Hereaposs everything you need to know about Good Friday, including why itaposs called Good Friday, and how it fits into the Easter story.What is Good Friday  Good Friday is a Christian holiday that commemorates the death of Jesus Christ. Christians believe that Jesus was betrayed by Judas after the Last Supper with his disciples on Maundy Thursday. He was nailed to a cross and crucied on Good Friday, despite the fact that he had done nothing wrong.  Why is it called Good Friday  While it seems strange to describe the day that somebody died as good, in this case it means more holy. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, good designates a day onwhich religious observance is held. The earliest known use of guode friday was in , in a text called The South English Legendary.Good Friday is also sometimes called Holy Friday or Great Friday.What are the Good Friday traditions  Good Friday traditions y around the world, but it is widely observed by Christians as a day of sorrow and mourning. In many countries people reenact Jesusapos walk to his death, with some even choosing to carry a cross on their back.Spain is particularly known for its celebration of aposHoly Weekaposwhich sees numerous processions and parades across the country. The most dramatic of these parades are usually held on Good Friday and Palm Sunday.Why do we eat Hot Cross Buns on Good Friday  There are a few dferent theories as to why people traditionally eat hot cross buns on Good Friday.One story suggests that a monk in the th century was the first to bake the yeasted sweet buns and mark them with a cross in honour of Good Friday.Theyaposre eaten to mark the end of Lent, as they contain the dairy products that were traditionally forbidden during the Christian period of fasting. An old English superstition suggested that hot cross buns baked on Good Friday would never go mouldy or spoil.Why do people eat fish on Good Friday  Many Christians choose to abstain from eating meat on Good Friday, and instead only eat fish. This is because eating meat was associated with feasts and celebration, and the Church felt it was inappropriate for the day that Jesus died.Fish is fine, as it was seen as a more everyday meal. Many people were fishermen, so there was nothing special or celebratory about dining on fish.

title: woman abandoned uber driver after
story: NewsWoman is abandoned by Uber driver after discovering she was going to abortion clinicThe -year-old student was told shed "regret it" and was left in the middle of nowhereShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsWoman ordering a taxi ride with mobile app on smartphone in the city"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter falling unexpectedly pregnant, a -year-old student found herself in a distressing situation.Having made the decision to have a termination , the unnamed woman found a clinic an hour away from her university in upstate New York which had appointment availability in three days. Not owning a car, the student booked an Uber for her .am appointment.It was awkward from the moment she got in the car.So at :am my Uber arrived and he immediately seemed uncomfortable, she wrote on Reddit . After about five minutes in the car, he asked, aposare we going to a planned parenthood apos I said no , but it set off alarm bells that he would even ask that. The destination I put in was just the name of the doctor and the address of the clinic, there was nothing that would suggest it was an abortion clinic. After a few more minutes he asked, aposare we going to an abortion clinic apos Stunned into silence by the question, the woman struggled to formulate an answer. I had no idea what to say, so I just remained quiet.    He then said aposI know itaposs none of my business, but...apos and proceeded to mention something about his we being pregnant, how awful the procedure was , and that aposthere is so much they don’t tell youapos. He then said aposyouaposre going to regret this decision for the rest of your leapos and that I was making a mistake. It was incredibly upsetting for the young woman to hear and she admits it took all of my strength not to start crying but I managed to keep it together by looking out the window and avoiding his gaze. Then things got weirder.    About halfway to the destination, he suddenly pulls over with no warning. There was a gas station and a closed antiques store, and around us was farmland and forest. He said aposIaposm sorry, but I canapost take you the rest of the way. I can take you back to [my city], but you wonapost be able to find another Uber out here.apos Crying, the woman got out of the car. She tried to call her parents, and then her boyfriend who calmed her down and told her to inform the clinic of what had happened and try to find a local cab company. My Uber driver hung around for about - minutes and asked once moreI wanted to go back with him and I declined. After he left, a cab came and I got to my appointment .    The next day, the student reported her driver to Uber and filed a police report the following day. A few days later she was told the driver had been banned, but the woman remains uncertain over whether she should pursue further legal action. People reading the womanaposs account have been disgusted by what she went through. Ew. That is HORRIFYING, one person wrote. He purposely set you up to miss your appointment. story: NewsWorlds smallest baby boy born at less than  weeks ready to leave hospitalRyusuke Sekino, from Japan, weighed less than a large apple when he was born in October last year via emergency caesarean section at Nagano Children’s Hospital in AzuminoShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsRyusuke Sekiya was born in October in Japan weighing as much as an apple "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A baby boy who was born weighing no more than a large apple is finally ready for the outside world.Ryusuke Sekino was dubbed the worldaposs smallest baby boy when he was delivered via emergency caesarean section at Nagano Children’s Hospital in Azumino after  weeks and five days of pregnancy.His mother, Toshiko, had experienced hypertension and doctors decided to perform the emergency surgery, reports the Japan Times.At  gramshe was lighter than the previous record holder, another Japanese boy who weighed just  grams when he was born last year in Tokyo.    That baby was discharged from Keio University Hospital in February. Ryusuke, born on October , measured just  centimetres tall and medical staff kept him in a neonatal intensive care unit. Tubes were used to feed him with cotton swabs also used to apply his motheraposs milk this his mouth. Nearly seven months later he now weighs more than three kilogrammes and it is expected he will be released from hospital this weekend.    His mother Toshiko said: “When he was born, he was so small, and it seemed ashe would break with a touch. I was so worried. “Now he drinks milk. We can give him a bath. I am happy that I can see him growing.” The smallest surviving girl was born in Germany in  weighing  grams, according to a registry put together by the University of Iowa of the world’s tiniest surviving babies. title: boss im facing busiest summer yet to get reds squad ready for new campaign
story: Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes today admitted he faces his busiest summer transfer window yet to rebuild his team.And McInnes also confirmed he will face a hectic window with “money at a premium” due to the construction of the £ million stadium and training complex.McInnes could have lost as many as  players at the end of the campaign who were with the Dons in January with Pittodrie deals for six players set to expire.Five loan players are also set toto their parent clubs.McInnes confirmed he is in constant dialogue with chairman Stewart Milne and vice-chairman Dave Cormack about securing a host of new signings during the summer transfer window.While having the backing of the board for the rebuild, he accepts the need to use the finances made available wisely.McInnes said: “This will be the busiest summer yet. There is a lot of work to be done as we anticipate losing a lot of key players.“Replacing key players has been a challenge, especially over the last couple of seasons.“We will need to work well and work smart as a club to get in the level of player we need.“There is constant discussion with the chairman and vice-chairman about these matters.“Money is at a premium at the minute as we have a stadium to pay for and a training ground.“We have to make sure we use what money we have wisely.”Aberdeen look set to lose captain Graeme Shinnie with Derby County closing in on signing the Scotland international.The Dons have offered the midfielder a deal that would make him the highest paid at the club and is understood to be for five years, including a testimonial.Shinnie travelled to Derby County last week for talks with Rams boss Frank Lampard. Derby are under a soft transfer embargo as the English Football League investigate their finances.However, it is understood that will be lted – allowing Derby to push through the signing of the Aberdeen captain.McInnes insists there has been no further development with Shinnie regarding Dons talks.Scotland international winger Gary Mackay-Steven is also set to go out of contract and is wanted by MLS side New York City, who made a formal approach to talk to him in the January window.Also out of contract is long-serving defender Andy Considine, who has made enough appearances to trigger a clause in his deal for a one-year extension.However, they have yet to thrash out another contract.Defender Mark Reynolds, on loan at Dundee United, has signed a pre-contract with the Tannadice club.Also with deals expiring are defender Greg Halford and keeper Tomas Cerny.Definitely exiting Pittodrie following the final game against Hibs are loan players James Wilson , Greg Stewart , Dom Balland Max Lowe . Defender Tommie Hobanhas already ed to his parent club having sustained season-ending cruciate ligament damage that required surgery.Stewart will become a free agent in the summer but it is understood he will sign on at Premiership rivals Rangers.Ball’s deal at Rotherham is also set to expire and McInnes has opened talks with the defender on a permanent move to Pittodrie.Hoban is also set to go out of contract at Watford in the summer but the Premier League club will oversee his rehabilitation from surgery. When he is fit – which will be well into next season – andHoban is still available, McInnes has not ruled out moving to sign him.However, the main priority is strengthening this summer with McInnes facing his busiest window in his six years at the club.He said: “We are well aware of what we have to do. We have players going out of contract and players on loan going back so we have a lot to do in the summer.“The first port of call is always the out-of-contract list and free agents, trying to bridge the gap that way.”There will be less than two months from the end of the season to the start of next.Whether the Dons kick-off the - campaign in the Europa League or the League Cup group stages still remains up in the air.Aberdeen face third-placed Kilmarnock tomorrow at Rugby Park. Leading the Dons on goal dference, Killie hold that third spot which brings immediate Europa League qualication.Fourth place will also bring Euro qualication should Celtic beat Hearts to retain the Scottish Cup.Whichever competition the Reds will begin their season in will matter little to their build-up or the time-line for signings.The Europa League first qualying round, which the Dons are in contention to qualy for, begins on Thursday July . The Betfred Cup group stage games begin just two days later on the weekend of July -.Is the potential of introducing so much fresh blood in the close season something McInnes relishes  “No. I would rather not have to replace players. I would rather keep my best players, but that is the challenge we face.”
